sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Urinary tract infection, chronic, Urease-producing; Adjunct: 250 mg (10-15 mg/kg/day) ORALLY divided 3-4 times a day; MAX 1.5 g/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Urinary tract infection, chronic, Urease-producing; Adjunct: initial, 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided 3-4 times a day

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: serum creatinine greater than 1.8 mg/dL, not to exceed 1 g/day divided every 12 hr; serum creatinine greater than 2.5 mg/dL, not recommended

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Urinary tract infection, chronic, Urease-producing; Adjunct
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Urolithiasis; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• serum creatinine greater than 2.5 mg/dL
  • urine infected by non-urease-producing organism
  • patients amenable to surgery and antimicrobials

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anemia; Coombs' negative hemolytic anemia can result
  • concomitant ethanol; skin rash
  • iron supplementation; acetohydroxamic acid can chelate heavy metals

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Acetohydroxamic acid is a derivative of hydroxylamine and acetyl acetate that reversibly blocks urease, a bacterial enzyme, thereby, preventing the hydrolysis of urea and ammonia production in urine contaminated with urea-splitting bacteria, such as Proteus. The therapeutic effect of the agent is attributed to the unchanged drug in the urine. The reduction of ammonia concentrations and pH improves the potency of certain antibiotics and raises the cure rate.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Oral: time to peak concentration, 0.25 h to 1 h

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• approximately 5 h to 10 h
  • Reduced renal function: prolonged

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • CBC and reticulocyte count; after 2 weeks of therapy and then at 3-month intervals for the duration of treatment
  • hepatic function

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, headache, anxiety, depression, or transient malaise.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hemolytic anemia.
  • Patient should take this drug on an empty stomach.
  • Tell patient to avoid drinking alcohol while taking this drug, as a skin rash may occur.
  • Advise patient to call healthcare professional if a dose is missed, as drug should be given on a regular schedule.
